issues.text: What is the substantial question which falls for decision in this appeal as to the legal effect of the deed EX. Y. 13 dated March 31, 1933 described as a deed of partition?

anchor.surface_text: Mudholkar, J. The substantial question which falls for decision in this appeal iS as tO the legal effect of a deed, EX. Y. 13, dated March 31. 1933 described in the paper-book as a deed of partition.

issues.text: Whether the validity of the transaction evidenced by the deed is affected by reason of the fact that the property comprised therein was at the time of its execution under the management of the Court of Wards?

anchor.surface_text: A subsidiary question also arises for companysideration which is, whether the validity of the transaction evidenced by the deed is affected by reason of the fact that the property companyprised therein was at the time of its execution, under the management of the Court of Wards.

issues.text: Whether the deed Ex. Y-13 is a family arrangement and as such binding upon the plaintiff?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document compromises conflicting claims of Gopinath and collaterals to Kanhaiyalal's estate; parties acted upon it by paying liabilities and obtaining Court of Wards release; final settlement as per document as whole and proviso; supported by Privy Council in Ramgouda Annagouda.

holdings.text: It seems to us abundantly clear that this document was in substance a family arrangement and, therefore, was binding on all the parties to it

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us abundantly clear that this document was in substance a family arrangement and, therefore, was binding on all  D  5SCI--16 the parties to it. Moreover it was acted upon by them. For, under certain terms thereof one of the parties, Gopinath, paid off certain liabilities

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document effects compromise of conflicting claims; recitals show recognition of rights despite prior disputes; suits compromised on same day; all interested parties involved; not temporary as per overall reading and proviso reserving only challenges to recitals not terms.

holdings.text: The rule of estoppel embodied in s. 115 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 would, therefore, shut out such pleas of the plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: Moreover acting on the terms of that document Gopinath paid monies to the Court of Wards for obtaining release from its management of the properties which were allotted to him. The rule of estoppel embodied in s. 115 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 would, therefore, shut out such pleas of the plaintiff.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff took benefits under transaction; Gopinath paid Court of Wards for release of allotted properties; conduct precludes challenging validity.

holdings.text: we have therefore no hesitation in holding that the plaintiff who has taken benefit under the transaction is not entitled to turn round and say that that transaction was of a kind which Kadma Kuar could not enter into and was therefore invalid

anchor.surface_text: The view that the transaction is a family arrangement is borne out by the decision of the Privy Council in Ramgouda Annagouda v Bhausaheb 1 . ... We have therefore no hesitation in holding that the plaintiff who has taken benefit under the transaction is not entitled to turn round and say that that transaction was of a kind which Kadma Kuar could not enter into and was therefore invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff bound as party who benefited; transaction valid family arrangement stronger than Ramgouda where all possible interests included despite no direct heirship.

holdings.text: Here the transaction in question is a family settlement entered into by the parties bona fide for the purpose of putting an end to the dispute among family members. Could it be said that this amounts to a transfer of or creation of an interest in property?

anchor.surface_text: Here the transaction in question is a family settlement entered into by the parties bona fide for the purpose of putting an end to the dispute among family members. Could it be said that this amounts to a transfer of or creation of an interest in property? For, unless it does, the action of Kadma Kuar would not fall within the purview of the aforesaid clause of s. 37.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Family settlement not alienation per Hiran Bibi and Khunni Lal; parties take by independent admitted title; not creation of interest.

holdings.text: in these circumstances we hold that the plaintiff is not entitled to press in aid the provisions of s. 37 a  of the U.P. Court of Wards Act

anchor.surface_text: Apart from that it may be pointed out that the two suits which were then pending were compromised with the full knowledge of the Court of Wards which was also a party to both the suits and the Court of Wards in fact released the estate by accepting from Gopinath monies which were due to it. In these circumstances we hold that the plaintiff is not entitled to press in aid the provisions of s. 37 a  of the U.P. Court of Wards Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not transfer/creation of interest; Court of Wards knew and accepted payments for release; distinguishes Man Singh as no family settlement or bona fide surrender there.

holdings.text: Courts give effect to a family settlement upon the broad and general ground that its object is to settle existing or future disputes regarding property amongst members of a family

anchor.surface_text: Courts give effect to a family settlement upon the broad and general ground that its object is to settle existing or future disputes regarding property amongst members of a family. The word family in the context is not to be understood in a narrow sense of being a group of persons who are recognised in law as having a right of succession or having a claim to a share in the property in dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Promotes amity and goodwill; consideration is mutual recognition of claims; applies even to near relations without strict heirship like in Ramgouda.

precedents.citation: Ramgouda Annagouda v Bhausaheb 1 ... L.R. 54 I.A. 396

anchor.surface_text: The view that the transaction is a family arrangement is borne out by the decision of the Privy Council in Ramgouda Annagouda v Bhausaheb 1 . The facts of the case which have been companyrectly summarised in the head numbere are briefly these A Hindu died in 1846, leaving a widow who survived until 1912, and a daughter. On the death of the widow A was heir to the estate. In 1868 the widow had alienated nearly the whole property by three deeds executed and registered on the same day. By the first deed she gave a property to her brother, by the second she sold half of another property to A, and by the third she sold the other half of that property to her son-in-law. The signature of each of the deeds was attested by the two other alienees. A who survived the widow for six years, did number seek to set aside any of the alienations. After his death his son and grandsons brought a suit to recover the whole property. Upon these facts the Privy Council held as follows Their Lordships companysider that the decision of this case depends upon how far the three documents can be taken as separate and independent, or so companynected as to form one transaction.

precedents.cited_proposition: Multiple documents can form part and parcel of one family settlement transaction to prevent future disputes among family members interested in the property
precedents.cited_holding: all the circumstances strongly point to the three documents being part and parcel of one transaction by which a disposition was made of Akkagoudas estate, such as was likely to prevent disputes in the future and therefore in the best interests of all the parties

anchor.surface_text: In Ramgouda Annagoudas 1 case, of the three parties to the settlement of a dispute companycerning the property of a deceased person one was his widow, other her brother and the tlhird her son-in-law. The two latter companyld number, under the Hindu Law, be regarded as the heirs of the deceased. Yet, bearing in mind their near relationship to the widow the settlement of the dispute was very properly regarded as a settlement of a family dispute. The companysideration for such a settlement, if one may put it that way, is the expectation that such a settlement will result in esablishing or ensuring amity and goodwill amongst persons bearing relationship with one another.

precedents.cited_proposition: Family settlement can include persons not legal heirs but near relations to the widow

precedents.citation: Mst. Hiran Bibi v. Mst. Sohan Bibi 1 ... A.I.R. 1914 P.C. 44

anchor.surface_text: In Mst. Hiran Bibi v. Mst. Sohan Bibi 1 approving the earlier decision in Khunni Lal v. Govind Krishna Narain 2 the Privy Council held that a companypromise by way of family settlement is in numbersense an alienation by a limited owner of family property. This case, therefore, would support the companyclusion that the transaction does number amount to a transfer.

precedents.case_name: Mst. Hiran Bibi v. Mst. Sohan Bibi
precedents.cited_proposition: A compromise by way of family settlement is in no sense an alienation by a limited owner of family property

precedents.citation: Khunni Lal v. Govind Krishna Narain 2 ... ILR. 33. An. 356

anchor.surface_text: In Mst. Hiran Bibi v. Mst. Sohan Bibi 1 approving the earlier decision in Khunni Lal v. Govind Krishna Narain 2 the Privy Council held that a companypromise by way of family settlement is in numbersense an alienation by a limited owner of family property. This case, therefore, would support the companyclusion that the transaction does number amount to a transfer.

precedents.case_name: Khunni Lal v. Govind Krishna Narain
precedents.cited_proposition: A compromise by way of family settlement is in no sense an alienation by a limited owner of family property

precedents.citation: Man Singh v Nowlakhbati 3 ... L.R. 53 I.AII.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sinha, however, companytends that the transaction amounts to creation of an interest by the ward in property which was under the superintendence of the Court of Wards and in support of his companytention relies on Man Singh v Nowlakhbati 3 . In the first place once it is held that the transaction being a family settlement is number an alienation, it cannot amount to the creation of an interest.

precedents.cited_proposition: Transaction purporting as surrender but not bona fide creates an interest in property under Court of Wards

precedents.citation: Rangasami Gounden v. Nachiappa Gounden 4 ... L.R. 46 I.A. 72

anchor.surface_text: For, as the Privy Council pointed out in Mst. Hiran Bibis 1 case in a family settlement each party takes a share in the property by virtue of the independent title which is admitted to that extent by the other parties. It is number necessary, as would appear from the decision in Rangasami Gounden v. Nachiappa Gounden 4 that every party taking benefit under a family. settlement must necessarily be shown to have, under the law, a claim to a share in the property.

precedents.cited_proposition: Not necessary that every party to family settlement has legal claim to share; possible claim or semblance sufficient if related

precedents.citation: Sureshwar Misser Maheshrani Misrain 1 ... L.R. 47 I.A. 233

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, reliance was placed before the Privy Council on the decision in Sureshwar Misser Maheshrani Misrain 1 in support of the appellants companytention that the transaction was valid. While distinguishing this case the Privy Council observed In that case there were serious disputes in the family as to title, and the next reversioners to the son sued the widow and her daughters to set aside the will of her husband under which the daughters were entitled to succeed to the immovable property on the death of the son without issue.

precedents.cited_proposition: Family compromise involving surrender by widow valid even if she receives maintenance portion
precedents.cited_holding: the companypromise was a bona fide surrender of the estate and number a device to divide it with the next reversioner, the giving of a small portion of it to the widow for her maintenance number being objectionable

R. 46 I.A. 72 .

anchor.surface_text: Moreover acting on the terms of that document Gopinath paid monies to the Court of Wards for obtaining release from its management of the properties which were allotted to him. The rule of estoppel embodied in s. 115 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 would, therefore, shut out such pleas of the plaintiff.
In these circumstances we hold that the plaintiff is not entitled to press in aid the provisions of s. 37 a  of the U.P. Court of Wards Act.

anchor.surface_text: The view that the transaction is a family arrangement is borne out by the decision of the Privy Council in Ramgouda Annagouda v Bhausaheb 1 . ... anchor.surface_text: Here the transaction in question is a family settlement entered into by the parties bona fide for the purpose of putting an end to the dispute among family members. Could it be said that this amounts to a transfer of or creation of an interest in property? For, unless it does, the action of Kadma Kuar would not fall within the purview of the aforesaid clause of s. 37.
In these circumstances we hold that the plaintiff is not entitled to press in aid the provisions of s. 37 a  of the U.P. Court of Wards Act.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from that it may be pointed out that the two suits which were then pending were compromised with the full knowledge of the Court of Wards which was also a party to both the suits and the Court of Wards in fact released the estate by accepting from Gopinath monies which were due to it. In these circumstances we hold that the plaintiff is not entitled to press in aid the provisions of s. 37 a  of the U.P. Court of Wards Act.
